title: Trump warns China that trade deal would get tougher if he’s re-elected
text:
Associated Press President Donald Trump

President Donald Trump warned China on Tuesday that a trade deal with the U.S. would be even tougher if he’s re-elected, as U.S. stocks were firmly lower following tit-for-tat tariffs imposed by Washington and Beijing.

CHINA TALKS

With U.S. and Chinese officials reportedly struggling to agree on the schedule for a planned meeting this month, Trump insisted “we are doing very well in our negotiations with China.”

Still, the president said in a tweet that the terms of a deal would get “MUCH TOUGHER!” if he wins reelection next year. He argued China would prefer to deal with a Democratic president, and said its economy would worsen if it waits until the election for an agreement with the U.S.

Read: The more Trump tweets, the worse it is for stocks, research finds.

U.S. stocks began September with losses after the implementation of new tariffs and weak manufacturing data. The Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA, -1.08% closed more than 280 points lower after tariffs on $112 billion in clothing and other imports from China went into effect on Sunday. China retaliated with new levies of its own. The S&P 500 index SPX, -0.69% lost 20 points and the Nasdaq COMP, -1.11% fell 89 points.

See Market Snapshot.

Also see: This ‘catastrophe’ could be Trump’s downfall, Nobel-winning economist says.

FEUD WITH LONDON MAYOR

Trump called London Mayor Sadiq Khan “incompetent” as he defended playing a round of golf on Monday.

Khan, with whom Trump has feuded previously, told Politico that Trump couldn’t attend World War II commemorations in Poland because he was “clearly busy dealing with a hurricane out on the golf course.” Trump canceled the weekend trip to monitor Hurricane Dorian and said on Twitter that his round of golf on Monday was “very fast.” The president said the mayor should stay out of U.S. affairs.
